The sun streamed through the window as I held my six-month-old baby, his tiny warm hand wrapped around my finger. In that moment, tears welled up—a complex mixture of joy, worry about his future with wars raging in Palestine, wonder, and love. The thought arose clearly: this one moment is enough for a life to be worth having lived. All the difficulty, the joy, the learning, the travel, the writing—this single moment of direct knowing contained everything. There is a feeling here that does not stem from interpretation or analysis; it simply is. The sense of love and joy when I’m with my baby, or the amazement when seeing dolphins in the ocean, isn’t interpreted. Somehow it’s clear, yet if people asked, I couldn’t defend it. In our modern world, this makes these ways of knowing lesser than the “more correct” answers about evolutionary adaptation or a curiosity that inspires us to learn and survive in a hostile world.

We face a crisis of knowledge where our most meaningful experiences are considered the least valid. Instead of embracing direct experience and trusting what we know in that moment, we overemphasize interpretations and explanations. Consider how this plays out in the history of human understanding. For centuries, astronomers observed the peculiar motion of planets in the night sky—sometimes appearing to move backward in their journey across the heavens. This “retrograde motion” demanded explanation. The transmitted knowledge that Earth was the center of the universe forced scholars to create increasingly complex mathematical models. They added circles within circles, epicycles upon epicycles, performing intellectual gymnastics to preserve their fundamental assumption. It wasn’t until we allowed ourselves to consider that perhaps we weren’t the center that a simpler, more elegant truth emerged. The planets’ apparent backward motion was the natural result of observing them from our own moving platform as we all orbit the sun.

This pattern repeats throughout history and within our own lives, including the question of how we experience time itself. Clock time is one where the ticking of a clock determines life, versus a more connected sense of natural rhythms. Consider waking up with the gradual warming light of the dawn, feeling the dew in the air, versus waiting anxiously for the digital clock to hit a certain hour. Clock time can feed into forethought, planning, projection, earning, extracting—getting the most “bang” from your buck, hoarding and expecting growth over time as interest accrues. In a different mode, guided by natural cycles, one might embrace harvest seasons, planting seasons, resting seasons, and acting seasons. This can lead to greater harmony with the environment and less frenetic extraction. Instead of waiting impatiently for the moment the clock strikes 5pm, you feel the workday’s natural conclusion as the sun sets, finishing a cycle that you belong to rather than exploit.

How can we possibly know what it feels like to live in a society that constructs entirely different mental architectures? Perhaps cultures that trust more in the unseen or have a foundational belief in the care of a most Merciful reality. I recall a story of a sheikh in a car accident where the driver was killed. The passenger rushes to check on the sheikh, blood running down his face, and the sheikh calmly says he is fine—he had set his intention and prayed before the journey, so whatever occurred was within that realm of care and meaning. What would it be like to inhabit a mind that can remain so calm and trusting in such urgent circumstances? Even imagining a small percentage of the population having that level of trust shifts our sense of what’s possible. This trust creates a new ground of being, connecting us beyond immediate fear and reminding us that, from a certain perspective, all gifts come from a source beyond our manipulation.

In my own life, I recall a moment in a refugee camp in Syria where I was given the most delicious meal I had in months. The culture of hospitality there was not a transaction—there was no ledger balancing out what was given and what would be returned. The non-intellectualized thought that “I have received, so I will give” created a lived reality of generosity. Gift economies can shift us from hoarding to relationship. Rather than relying on the integral measure of wealth (how much I have in my bank), we might consider the derivative (how much flows through, how we participate in a living dynamic of exchange). This sort of trust-based approach to economics aligns more closely with human presence and natural rhythms than with a strict, clock-driven and interest-based system that seeks accumulation and leverage.

Knowing what is beautiful and Good fills the heart with a kind of song, but enacting it requires effort and friction. Suppose I want to visit a sick person: I must scrape the snow off my car, drive to the hospital, buy flowers, spend time. This friction is transformative. By choosing to enact beauty rather than remain in comfort, I sand down my self-absorption. Each time I choose someone’s well-being over my own convenience, I integrate a deeper sense of connection and moral presence. Doing this repeatedly can create a different sort of internal architecture—one where concern for others is not an abstraction but a lived reality. Over time, we become the kind of people who find it natural to give, to share, to participate in the cycle of reciprocity and care. If we consider the human body and mind as something that can be hollowed out by self-absorption or filled with vibrant life by consciously choosing what’s Good, then these acts of kindness, even if small, fill the emptiness with beauty.

Historical examples also show how cultures respond differently to technology and power. Japan, after mastering the gun, famously decided to give it up, not wanting to allow a weapon that requires no discipline or honing of virtue to become widespread. This question of who we empower with technology remains critical today. We mass-produce complex tools that can reshape entire societies, yet we do so without ensuring that those wielding such power have developed themselves ethically. We search for metrics of progress—GDP growth, technological advancement, profit margins—but in doing so we might lose sight of the person in need right in front of us, the soil that nourishes us, the fragile interconnections that sustain life, and the beauty that can be enacted in this very moment.

We are tempted to strategize and find the perfect metrics to measure success, but perhaps the most meaningful “metric” is the act of goodness itself. Like the child who throws one starfish back into the sea despite the countless others left behind, it matters to that one starfish, and it matters to that child. Each such act recreates a reality of mercy and compassion on Earth, a reality that cannot be fully captured by numbers. By focusing on our purification, on taking ourselves to account (muhasaba), on reviewing our intentions and actions (muraja3a), we can become more aware of what we are doing with our time, our capabilities, and our opportunities. Slowly, this leads us to align ourselves more with a sense of wholeness and ethical participation in the world’s unfolding story.

Flow states, in the psychological sense, do not guarantee ethical action. One can be deeply engrossed in an activity that is harmful. But if we bring the same presence, trust, and openness into what we choose to do, then this immersion can be coupled with right intention, resulting in acts that not only feel seamlessly integrated but also contribute to something good and harmonious. At that point, we are not just living life as a series of transactions or ticking boxes off a to-do list governed by the clock and external demands. We are participating in the world as a dynamic, living tapestry, where each choice creates a new pattern and each moment carries the potential for kindness, generosity, and understanding.

Ultimately, the greatest gift is existence itself, which we have not earned. We arrive in a world we did not create, among people we did not choose, in environments shaped by countless converging forces of nature and history. Recognizing this can open us to awe and humility. Instead of looking for a perfect formula or metric, we can learn to be present enough to see what each moment asks of us: sometimes to give rather than hoard, sometimes to plant rather than reap, sometimes to rest rather than push forward, and sometimes to stand in wonder and gratitude at the simple fact that we are here at all.

In doing so, we create a kind of resonance, a lived architecture of trust and care that might slowly spread through our personal relationships, our communities, and perhaps beyond. We do not have to solve it all or explain it all. The mere act of experiencing and responding wholeheartedly to what is given—whether it’s the chance to help a sick person, share a meal in a refugee camp, marvel at dolphins in the ocean, or hold a baby’s hand in a sunlit room—is enough to show that another way of relating to knowledge, time, trust, and meaning is not only possible but already present, waiting quietly for our recognition.

Your life would start as a minuscule few cells, moving around in a tiny sphere stretched through time towards a period where all your composite molecules will once again be scattered in an earth-shaped orb. In this view watching outside time and space one can imagine that each snapshot also must have within it consciousness and experience. Presence to me feels like it can be expanded about 3/4 seconds of existence. Perhaps as Shakespeare says, there's nothing good or bad and that thinking makes it so - we can imagine that the duration of a ruminative thought of self dislike can be the sense / being / snapshot for your consciousness in that frame in the time sausage forever. There's no going back. Otherwise the sense of self acceptance / like, trust in yourself being as beautiful as you can be, given the singular nature of the time sausage and all the other elements within it - that's a good place to live "forever" in a sense.
Making a plan and sticking to it is one of the critical success factors no matter the initial feedback we might have. One of the worst ways to lose money is jumping into the stock market greedily seeing the price go up and then when the correction inevitably comes selling in terror as everything tumbles - only to watch as the stock market performs stable and smoothly in a multi-year perspective. Patience and planning, vs responding with greed and fear can be seen easily in markets as they are a sort of mirror to the feeling of the market.
The book "The Gift" by Lewis Hyde documents gift cultures, the idea that art can be a gift and maybe is a gift of connection.
Historians debate for ages why Zheng He had ships with 28,000 sailors and visited 30 countries yet didn't colonize a single one, similarly there's The Needham Puzzle which asks why didn't China develop science and industrialize when it had the means to. Other historians question why the Ottoman empire didn't industrialize, seeming to take as a given that western society's developmental direction is progress and that they "should" have. The outcomes might not have been politically advantageous as these countries were dominated by Europeans militarily. There are some interesting stories of people from the Ottoman empire being asked about European wealth, big buildings, wide streets, yet seeming not to be excited by this view of glamorous progress. A society can be judged by how it treats its weak, or perhaps, we can judge a society by how much anti-depressants they prescribe.
Transmitted knowledge can be seen as things we learn from others, including science, and transmitted elements from religious doctrines. Derived knowledge takes a mind and a world and contemplation. The book Hayy Ibn Yaqzan follows the story of someone on a deserted island who in their primordial knowledge seeking and enaction essentially ends up practicing the Muslim faith, an ancient story.
The trust that people have create a new ground on which to stand, especially without fear of hunger or death it creates a different way to interact. Today we want smart contracts that are incorruptible, what if our souls were, what if there were people in the world where dishonor and going against their word/trust would be worse than death? It seems to create a platform from which we can connect/exchange that is beautiful rather than mechanical and efficient. I believe a perfect system where our souls are not exposed to the reality of ethical action, and the friction that choosing the Good provides, is in fact the opposite of a perfect system. It's preventing the most beautiful parts of us from growing, causing atrophy in the muscles of perception and enaction of The Good - leading to smooth and slippery exchange of "Goods and services" except are they goods if the bodies they provide nutrition to are empty of beauty? Are they really serving us if the will that directs those services has not been refined through repeated interaction with ethical training and action?
Think of the state of Flow from Csikszentmihalyi - the capacity at wondering if you're there is occupied with engagement. CopyRetryBGcontinue the essayEditCreating Ethical Friction
Knowing what is beautiful and Good is one thing - it fills the heart with song. I want to give time to visit a sick person, then there's the effort of going and clearing the snow off the car and driving to the hospital, buying flowers, and spending time with the person. That process is effortful; there's friction there. You choose to become the goodness that you imagined.
In the light of oneness, this friction sands down the self-absorbed, individuated part of you that would rather want for itself - coffee from that fancy shop rather than flowers for that person, sleep in your warm bed rather than scraping snow off the car. The self-absorbed self is shrunk every time we prioritize beauty and goodness. The process of doing this enacts beauty and goodness and makes it a reality in the world.
I was once in a refugee camp in Syria where I was given the most delicious meal I had in months. The desire to be generous to guests, the hospitality culture, reveals something fundamental about trust and gift-giving. The (non-intellectuated) thought that "I have received so I will give" creates a different kind of social reality. It's critical that the gift doesn't become a transaction - this is related to the disindividuating practices.
Technology and Worthiness
Consider Japan's decision, documented in the book "Giving up the Gun," where after becoming world experts, they chose to stop making guns and muskets. They saw the disgrace in how someone with no training, no honing of the self, could shoot and kill a samurai with decades of discipline and a protective warrior ethic. Who do we empower with our technologies if our selves are not refined? Do we want to give the power of the Gods to those who don't discipline themselves to earn it?
When college dropouts can build technologies that transform the world before they have learned how to mourn the loss of their parents, or raise a toddler with patience and love, we must question our direction. The metrics might be the problem - coming up with a measure takes away from the quality of creating the situation of beauty. For instance, if we measure number of impoverished people, we are measuring a number instead of knowing the person.
The Starfish and the Boy
There's a story of a child on a beach throwing starfish back into the water one at a time. There are hundreds of starfish. The father asks, "You know it doesn't matter, you can't save them all," and the boy responds, "It matters to this one" as he throws it into the ocean. The idea is that it doesn't just matter to the starfish, it matters to the boy. The boy has created the reality of mercy on earth where indifference is the "rational" response.
The shift in thinking is to focus on our purification and action and creating situations for this rather than thinking about systems and metrics only to intervene strategically. The most strategic thing to do is to make real Goodness and beauty. This makes it... real.
The Gift of Existence
The ultimate gift is the gift of existence which we didn't do anything for and from which all other gifts derive. To see the world as a constant paying it forward of the ultimate gift, transferring, shifting, never being consumed or reduced is a way to begin to trust. Perhaps I go hungry, yet the beauty of a world which exists generously with gifts and offerings and sharing and loving others as oneself - perhaps because the unitary consciousness sees this as true.
Success should be in every step for a king, president and shop owner. Success is in right action at the right time derived from right seeing. These, in aggregate, create a more beautiful world, although it doesn't matter. What matters is that we become beautiful in trying, that we make real the possibility of beauty and trust in a world increasingly structured around fear and extraction. The path is not one to follow but a reality to create, moment by moment, choice by choice, in the eternal now where all possibility resides. CopyRetryBGContinueEditReconciling Science and Spirituality
The idea of a scientist curiously and openly attempting to see and understand brings awe, wonder, curiosity. But science directed by intentionality seeking to make use of the operations of the natural world for the benefit of the inventor is different, blinded, and I believe directs science toward a world of less awe and more mechanization and harm.
Consider the Fritz Haber process, which transforms nitrogen from the air into fertilizer. It was first invented to build bombs for the German war machine. Today, that abundance of nitrogen has led to feeding millions of people - yet the food is not as nutritious, and how many diseases of malnutrition do we have? What about the dead land and the dead zone in the Gulf of Mexico from nitrogen-based fertilizer runoff? Contrast this with the discovery of penicillin - an accident, a gift, acknowledged as such by Pasteur through his rejection of patent rights. This demonstrates how openness and acceptance of knowledge through wonder and curiosity can influence those who receive it. It's all a gift, why not give and share of its benefit?
Reviewing and Aligning
Bringing our innovation and creativity in line with our sense of oneness with all things requires constant review. In the Muslim tradition, this is called muraja3a (reviewing) and muhasaba (taking ourselves to account). A day that starts with intention and ends with reviewing allows us to constantly stay in tune. Like a tuning fork near another one, we can listen for the resonances and move. The 99 names, and infinitely many more, are in a dynamic dance everywhere within and without us. Our role can be to align to that, and then slowly, slowly watch our movements come into harmony with that which is the origin of harmony.
When we participate in discovery and innovation, we can always review: is this encouraging harmony and balance? Is it beautiful? The natural direct knowledge we see and know about the harmony and balance of the world is not foreign to us. As we learn and understand more about how it works, we can also learn how best to participate.
Conclusion: Towards a New Architecture of Mind
We stand at a critical juncture in human history, where our technological and scientific capabilities have far outpaced our ethical and spiritual development. We have the power to transform the planet, yet we struggle to transform ourselves. The path forward lies not in abandoning rationality or science, but in integrating them with a deeper wisdom, a trust in the fundamental goodness and beauty of existence.
This requires a new architecture of mind, one that balances the analytical with the intuitive, the quantitative with the qualitative, the individual with the collective. It requires cultivating a direct knowing, a way of being in harmony with natural cycles and rhythms, a trust in the abundance of the universe. It means creating friction where it matters - in the daily choice to prioritize beauty and goodness over self-interest and comfort.
This is not an easy path. It demands constant reflection, review, and realignment. It requires the courage to question our metrics of success, to value the immeasurable, to prioritize the development of the soul alongside the development of technology. But it is a necessary path if we are to create a future worth inhabiting, a world of beauty, balance, and harmony.
In every moment, we have the opportunity to participate in this creation, to align our actions with our highest intentions, to let go of fear and trust in the fundamental benevolence of the universe. This is the way of beauty and trust, the path of heart in a heartless world. It begins with a single step, a single choice, a single moment of presence. And it begins now.
